Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Glycosylation as a primary contributor to cell fate-specific membrane capacitance
Award.AbstractNarration:
Neural stem cells in the central nervous system form specialized cells (neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes) to build the brain and spinal cord. Unfortunately, studying the cells that make each of these specialized cell types has been complicated because they are difficult to distinguish from one another. Through interdisciplinary studies combining biology with biophysics, Dr. Flanagan's group has found novel differences defining these cells, which can be used to obtain pure populations of each cell type for further study. The project will use cell biological, biophysical, and molecular experiments to identify key characteristics of cells forming neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes. These studies will uncover important differences in these cells and help scientists understand how the formation of the brain and spinal cord is controlled. A firm grasp on the mechanisms driving the development of the brain and spinal cord will lead to a better understanding of central nervous system disorders. Truly interdisciplinary studies such as these have the potential to unlock many biological mysteries. While interdisciplinary research has been recognized as important, it has been harder to accomplish.

This project is firmly committed to interdisciplinary science, and the proposed activities will contribute to preparing the scientists of tomorrow that will need to be trained to think beyond disciplinary boundaries. This project will expose students at multiple levels (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) to the importance of interdisciplinary research since studies coupling biology with fields such as engineering and biophysics will be critical for future progress in the biological sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to provide a deeper understanding of the specific cell types formed in the neural stem cell lineage, particularly focusing on progenitors that generate either neurons or astrocytes during brain development. Studies honed in on plasma membrane characteristics that indicate whether cells will generate neurons or astrocytes. Experiments (1) tested whether cells that form either neurons or astrocytes have distinct electrophysiological properties (membrane capacitance) and differ in cell surface sugars, (2) quantified effects of sugars on membrane capacitance, and (3) tested predicted associations of cell surface sugars with neuron- and astrocyte-biased cells in the developing brain. These studies utilized an interdisciplinary approach coupling a knowledge of stem cell biology with the engineering and biophysics expertise necessary to study whole cell membrane capacitance.

Identifying the key cell surface components that distinguish different neural progenitor populations has profound implications for understanding the basic processes occurring during brain development. Experiments of the project determined that a key phenotypic difference in progenitors is cell surface sugars, which could indicate cell-type specific markers, further expand the knowledge of the distinct cell biological differences that define progenitors, and identify new ways in which progenitor responses to extracellular cues are regulated.

Cell surface sugars attached to plasma membrane receptors controls their binding to ligands such as growth factors, morphogens, extracellular matrix molecules, and cell-cell adhesion proteins. Additionally, these sugars affect the residence time of receptors on the cell surface.  Studies in this project showed that differences in the cell surface sugars of progenitors contributes to their distinct membrane capacitance values, determines whether they will form neurons or astrocytes, and likely provides specific regulation of receptors to guide the neuron/astrocyte fate choice as occurs during brain development.

Whole cell membrane capacitance is a label-free biomarker reflecting cell fate in many stem cell lineages. The outcomes of this project focusing on the neural lineage reveal basic cell biological mechanisms that likely regulate fate choice and cell differentiation across many stem cell populations, indicating the broad applicability of the results.

The education component of this project focused on the importance of an inter-disciplinary approach to science. Goals were to provide training for undergraduates, graduate students, and K-12 students (through an informal science program with Girls, Inc) in which biology was coupled with fields such as engineering and biophysics. The principal investigator is firmly committed to inter-disciplinary research and believes the scientists of tomorrow should be trained to think beyond disciplinary boundaries.

A total of 11 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, and 3 post-graduate trainees were mentored and trained over the course of the project. The vast majority of these trainees have continued in scientific careers, creating a workforce well trained in inter-disciplinary science. The public outreach component of the project involved collaboration with a critical community partner, Girls Inc. Girls Inc. provides after school and summer programs to approximately 3,800 girls at 48 sites throughout Orange County in California.  Many of the girls are from minority groups not well represented in science (72% Hispanic or Latina and 3% Black or African-American). Furthermore, 96% of the girls come from homes with an annual family income of $50,000 or less.  As such, these girls do not have the financial resources to supplement their science education beyond that offered in schools.  However, Girls Inc is clearly having an impact since only 60% of U.S. college women graduate but 90% of Girls Inc scholars earn degrees. Girls Inc. equips girls with the skills and knowledge to successfully prepare for college, graduate, and move ahead with their careers. Our education project was was well received, not only by the girls who truly enjoyed the science but also by the staff at Girls Inc.  They were thrilled to see the girls so engaged and brought several team members by to observe our program.

The public outreach component of this project may improve the public’s perception of science and the importance of science to our daily lives. By involving young people and training them in interdisciplinary science, we reach not only those participants but by association their families and friends. Direct contact between scientists and the public leads to an improved understanding of the critical role science plays in our society.  In addition, the project brings science experiences to disadvantaged youth, giving them exposure to skills that will eventually help them succeed in the marketplace.
